page.description: Options for configuring SSL support on the Application Server.

discussion.p: The Application Server optionally supports SSL for secure, encrypted transmissions. This support is particularly valuable in e-commerce applications.

The Application Server responds on the port specified on the General tab of the Control Panel. If you use port 81 and enable SSL, your URL would be https://:81. If you run SSL on port 443 instead, you can simplify your URL to https://.

section.important: If you have SSL enabled, the Application Server will not respond to any http:// URL, no matter what number port you are using.

item.name: Enable SSL
item.description: Enables or disables SSL on the server.

item.name: Server Port
item.description: The default SSL port is 443. Any other port will require tha you use a URL including the port number (e.g. *[ui:https://mysite.org:444]*

description.p: The minimum TLS protocol version supported by the Classic Application Server can be specified using the *[ui:Minimum Protocol Version]*. TLS 1.3 is the most recent protocol and generally considered to be the most secure. Setting the minimum TLS version to 1.3 will disable TLS 1.2 and provide what is currently considered the highest level of security. Note however that not all web browsers or operating systems support TLS 1.3. Site administrators should evaluate the needs of their users before modifying this setting.
The following TLS protocols are available:

item.name: TLS 1.2
item.description: Default setting. TLS 1.2 may not be supported on older browsers. See *[extlink:https://caniuse.com/#feat=tls1-2]* for details on browser compatibility.

item.name: TLS 1.3
item.description: Disables TLS 1.2. TLS 1.3 may not be supported in some browsers. See *[extlink:https://caniuse.com/#feat=tls1-3]* for details on browser compatibility.

item.name: SSL Certificate File
item.description: The file containing the SSL certificate.

item.name: Private Key File
item.description: The private key file that matches the specified SSL certificate.

item.name: Private Key Password
item.description: The password for the private key file, if required.

item.name: Certificate Chain File
item.description: The certificate's chain file, if required or provided by the Certificate Authority. This is sometimes also referred to as the "intermediate certificate" or "intermediate bundle".

item.name: SSL Cipher List
item.description: A list of SSL ciphers to use.

item.name: Generate a Self-Signed Certificate
item.description: Creates a self-signed certificate for the server. A self-signed certificate is useful for testing intranet applications.

item.name: Generate a CSR (Certificate Signing Request)
item.description: Used when purchasing a certificate from a Certificate Authority (CA).

item.name: HTTP Strict Transport Security
item.description: Configure how HTTP Strict Transport Security is used on the server.

item.name: Enabled
item.description: Enable or disable HTTP Strict Transport Security.

section.title: About SSL Certificates
section.description: A certificate enables a web server to tell its web clients its name and its public key, to be used for encrypted (SSL) communications. There are two types of certificates.

item.name: Self-signed - good for testing and internal private applications, but not suitable for external public applications
Issued by trusted companies, such as Thawte and Verisign - good for public applications

description.p: To get a certificate from a trusted company:

step.description: Generate a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) for the server where the certificate will be installed. Be sure to keep the private key created as part of the CSR generation. It will be needed when you receive your certificate.
Send this information to one of the trusted companies. Typically, you will paste it into a web form, but the methods vary.
Click the *[ui:[browse]]* Browse button to navigate to and select the *[ui:SSL Certificate File]*.
Click to navigate to and select the *[ui:Private Key File]*.
Enter your password into the Private Key Password control. This is the password chosen during CSR generation.
